name: rare earth oxides production, from rare earth carbonate concentrate | samarium oxide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23108/documentation

For the processing of rare earth carbonates (extracted from ion-adsorption clays) to produce rare earth oxides in the Fujian region of China. This dataset is based on the following publication: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484 and the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue University. Specific modifications were made in order to make the dataset more transparent.;Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Currently, mining and processing of rare earth elements is predominantly carried out in China, where they are extracted mainly via open pit mining of bastnäsite and/or monazite deposits or the leaching of ion-adsorption clays.;Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018).

The activity starts with the processing of rare earth carbonate concentrate.

The activity ends with the production of individual rare earth oxides.

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is valid for the whole corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset refers to the extraction (calcination) and refining (solvent extraction) of individual rare earth oxides, obtained from mined rare earth carbonates. ""After drying and calcination, 90−92% mixed REOs are produced. The REO mixture from the leaching process undergoes a combined solvent extraction process at a facility in Southern China. The process inventory includes conversion to RE chlorides, repeated SX using organic solvents such as P204 and P507 and precipitation using oxalic acid. The high purity individual RE precipitate is further roasted to obtain separated pure oxides."" Source: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on the following publication: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484.   
All exchanges from/ to the environment and from/to the technosphere were calculated using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university. This excel-based software acts as a supporting tool to the abovementioned publication. Individual exchanges such as sulfidic tailings and wastewater which were not contained in the original datasets have been added for completness purposes and their calculation is based on mass balance.
